subject: Move login state machine to bmcweb
commitMessage:
Move login state machine to bmcweb

This commit attempts to move the handling of login/logout out of
javascript, and into more basic forms.  This simplifies login handling
overall, and means that no javascript is executing until a user is
logged in, which means that a large number of files can be "hidden"
behind 401 return codes.

Advantages:
1. A number of people have complained about a "bug" in bmcweb, where
lack of phosphor-webui causes an infinite redirect.  This is a problem,
as bmcweb contains its own redfish rendering UI, yet relies on the
phosphor-webui login page.  At one point, there was an effort to move
this UI into phosphor-webui, but it was deemed a mediocre idea, as
redfish is an API, and can exist without any UI (as some users wish to
do).  This patch fixes the whole scope of the issue, by having one
common login form for all routes, including the webui, and breaks the
dependency to require phosphor-webui to be installed.

2. The routes list in webassets.hpp is a hack, and causes an
architectural problem, as individual routes now have to be aware of
other routes existence, as well as adds the possibily that someone could
inject a nefarious route through the filesystem, that allows things
through the whitelist.  In practice, this is handled, but requires a
very complex state machine that combines logic in the router, and the
webassets to function properly.  THis patchset moves the allow list to
something much simpler, easier to audit for correctness, and something
that very likely optimizes better.

3. We are no longer running ANY javascript in an unauthenticated
context.  This means that our whole javascript packages is almost
entirely out of scope for any sort of pre-auth attack.  This is good, as
bmcweb is already a place we have to do this.

4. This unifies the mutual TLS and webui auth mechanisms into a single
spot, so the "IsAuthenticated" header is used everywhere.  Not special
casing mtls seems like a good idea.

5. It clears the way for an OAUTH login type, which would likely require
a similar handshake with bmcweb.  (note, this is conjecture based on
experience.  I have not built an oauth patch to verify this yet)

6. Lack of javascript and static files will mean that bmcweb is less able to be
fingerprinted to determine its version, especially in the case where
Redfish static files are hidden behind an auth mechanism.

Downsides:
1. It adds a couple branches to the webui login routines, for handling
both the case where this is installed in bmcweb, and the case where it's
not.  This is somewhat already split, given mutual TLS auth, but this
makes some of the routes more different.  The old routes have been left
so remote development should still work, and given that this branch is
never used in a "real" deployment anymore, and only adds about 4 lines
of "dead" code in the final product, it seems reasonable.

2. It gives bmcweb more ownership of css (it already had some) than it
previously had.  This seems like a reasonable compromise.

Details:
This patch tries to pull the openbmc login page style "as-is" as much as
possible to avoid the conflict, and to make the change invisible to
users.  If any significant differences are
seen, please point them out, as that is not the intent, with the
exception of the empty validation, which was previously done in
javascript.  This is now done server-side.

TODO:
The "bad password" redirect isn't quite working as intended.  This needs
triaged.
The next handler in the /login route needs to be adjusted to check for
valid routes before it redirects, similar to what javascript has done.

Tested:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-webui/+/35453

Loaded the webui patch, and logged in, logged out.  Observed proper
behavior of the UI.
